page.title: 03Burgh Marsh
page.content: Situated at the confluence of the River Eden and the Solway Firth, Burgh Marsh is sea-washed grassland with areas of quicksand. At the eastern end of the Marsh there is a monument to King Edward I. Many sheep are brought from the fells in the autumn and are kept on the Marsh until the spring. They are looked after by the Marsh Shepherd who ensures that they are kept safe. Low tide means he can go out at any time on his Honda three wheeler, but before a high tide he has to be sure that the animals are on the high marsh. At dusk Mr. Brown drives the sheep to the high marsh, the sheep get used to this routine. Once settled they don't move. In the winter of 1984-85 only 14 out of 1200 sheep were lost. From spring until autumn cattle occupy the marsh.
